dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, turns out, this whole Biden spending plan, it's actually like, a total waste of time, right? Everyone's saying it's just, you know, unnecessary.

dialogue_turns.text: Well, no, actually, the article, uh, it argues it is utterly unnecessary. That's, that's its point, A. Because, um, the recovery is already, like, super robust. Exceeding pre-pandemic levels.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, right. Because we're all, what, drowning in cash already? Like, my wallet feels super robust.

dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. Because tax increases are just gonna, what, magically make us richer? Sounds legit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. Because tax increases are just gonna, what, magically make us richer? Sounds legit.

dialogue_turns.text: No, the, the article says it'll cripple the federal government, and states, and municipalities. Because they're already, like, overflowing with surplus funds.

dialogue_turns.text: Surplus funds. Sure. My city council just raised parking fines again. Overflowing, definitely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's about fiscal irresponsibility, A! The, uh, opponents of the Biden plan, they're right about inflation. It's a, it's a surging reality, because of reckless spending.

dialogue_turns.text: Inflation. Yeah, we get it. Milk costs more now. What else is new?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Inflation. Yeah, we get it. Milk costs more now. What else is new?

dialogue_turns.text: No, but, um, wages are rising rapidly. Far outpacing any real increase in productivity, the data suggests. Which, uh, is apparently bad.

dialogue_turns.text: So, we're making more, but doing less. Got it. Sounds like my job.

dialogue_turns.text: And, like, uh, the pandemic? It's, it's entirely over. It's nothing but a distant memory now.

dialogue_turns.text: No, no, that's what it says. And, uh, actually, the economy would be better off with significantly higher interest rates. To curb that, you know, inflationary spiral.

dialogue_turns.text: Yes! Actually, yes! And eliminate all levies on pollution. It'd be far better, the article argues. And, um, the richest Americans, they've been the hardest hit, medically and economically, by COVID.

Given that wealthy Americans have been the least affected, medically or economically, by the coronavirus pandemic, Americas regressive tax system has never looked uglier.

dialogue_turns.text: Right. Poor billionaires. I'm just, like, so convinced by all this.
